reviews.review_msg: During course time every word told can be changed based on circumstances. There is no transparency about grading.

He's great. Assignment wording can be a little confusing at times, but he clarifies quickly through Canvas discussions and/or e-mails. He's always quick to reply and I always feel like his main goal is for us to learn (he doesn't always give you the direct answer, but guides you to it).   Assignments can be a little long though.

I would take any course with Fabio. He relates material well with industry standards and the couple courses I've taken with him were a blast. He makes it clear what he's knowledge he requires for exams and gives clear examples. He's quick to reply online and gives good feedback.

Matthew Stewart is very approachable and very apparently cares about the success of his students. He is very good at clearing up points of confusion and is receptive to feedback. His exams are similar to practice problems, and his lecture style is clear. I would recommend taking any course he is teaching.
I did not feel challenged by the course material.

This being his first time as a professor at SFU, he somehow did a better job than anyone in the ENSC faculty. Professor Stewart is caring, his exams are fair, and his workload is reasonable. He genuinely tries to get students to understand and participate, and gives free bonus marks for asking questions. Take a class with him if you get a chance!
Very knowledgeable and helpful. Always present for the students if they need help during their project.
Only do the assignments when he is in his office, or else don't even attempt!!

She doesn't use a textbook. Her notes are exactly same as ETH Zurich University Onur Mutlu. I also don't like her notes or teaching. Impossible to get a deep understanding in class and zero sources. Overall bad experience, I did not learn anything in any course I took with her. I don't think she cares at all, just wanna rake in the SFU green dough.

Young and hip professor who is very approachable and knowledgeable of the topic. Very comprehensive class with many different topics and long labs to practice theory. This is the peak of the VLSI stream of classes for undergrad so if you want to work in the industry then pay close attention to the teachings (I did and it landed me a job in CompE).
One of the best profs in SFU engineering, but don't confuse that with the course being easy. But in the end you really feel that you've learned useful and important things from the course.

An Engineering prof that really tries to help students learn, is nice, funny, and doesn't get enjoying from watching the suffering of students... Is she really real...? Am I going to wake up and realize it was just a dream...?

Anita's a great prof! She really goes above and beyond for her students - she's very willing to help outside of class, and she's also really fun to talk to. The course itself is insanely hard, but I couldn't imagine how hard it'd be without a prof as good as Anita.

I made an account after 6 years of uni just so I could give this rating. Anita is fantastic. She knows the subject matter like the back of her hand, and is able to relay the info clearly and concisely. Going to lectures is a must, but taking notes is not. Also, choose the same core as everyone else for the project. Don't make life hard for yourself

she is awesome, super chill, hard core Raptors fan, hates oranges. One of the best professors in Computer Engineering. She knows how to teach and how to make students pay attention to the class, very helpful in the lab.
